And now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide a preliminary cruise, Ahab,â€”all other whaling waters sweptâ€”seemed to have chased his foe into an ocean-fold, to slay him the more securely there; now, that he found himself hard by the very latitude and longitude where his tormenting wound had been inflicted; now that a vessel had been spoken which on the very day preceding had actually encountered ğŸ³;â€”and now that all his successive meetings with variousğŸš¢s contrastingly concurred to show the demoniac indifference with which the â¬œ ğŸ‹ tore his hunters, whether sinning or sinned against; now it was that there lurked a something in the old manâ€™s ğŸ‘€, which it was hardly sufferable for feeble souls to see. As the unsetting polar star, which through the livelong, arctic, six monthsâ€™ night sustains its piercing, steady, central gaze; so Ahabâ€™s purpose now fixedly gleamed down upon the constant midnight of the gloomy crew. It domineered above them so, that all their bodings, doubts, misgivings, fears, were fain to hide beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a single spear or leaf.

In this foreshadowing interval too, all humor, forced or natural, vanished. Stubb no more strove to raise a smile; â­ğŸ’² no more strove to check one. Alike, joy and sorrow, hope and fear, seemed ground to finest dust, and powdered, for the time, in the cğŸª”ed mortar of Ahabâ€™s iron soul. Like machines, they dumbly moved about the deck, ever conscious that the old manâ€™s despot eye was on them.

But did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential hours; when he thought no glance but one was on him; then you would have seen that even as Ahabâ€™s ğŸ‘€ so awed the crewâ€™s, the inscrutable Parseeâ€™s glance awed his; or somehow, at least, in some wild way, at times affected it. Such an added, gliding strangeness began to invest the thin Fedallah now; such ceaseless shudderings shook him; that the men looked dubious at him; half uncertain, as it seemed, whether indeed he were a mortal substance, or else a tremulous shadow cast upon the deck by some unseen beingâ€™s body. And that shadow was always hovering there. For not by night, even, had Fedallah ever certainly been known to slumber, or go below. He would stand still for hours: but never sat or leaned; his wan but wondrous ğŸ‘€ did plainly sayâ€”We two watchmen never rest.

Nor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners now step upon the deck, unless Ahab was before them; either standing in his pivot-hole, or exactly pacing the planks between two undeviating limits,â€”the main-mast and the mizen; or else they saw him standing in the cabin-scuttle,â€”his living foot advanced upon the deck, as if to step; his hat slouched heavily over his ğŸ‘€; so that however motionless he stood, however the days and nights were added on, that he had not swung in his hammock; yet hidden beneath that slouching ğŸ©, they could never tell unerringly whether, for all this, his ğŸ‘€ were really closed at times; or whether he was still intently scanning them; no matter, though he stood so in the scuttle for a whole hour on the stretch, and the unheeded night-damp gathered in beads of dew upon that stone-carved coat and ğŸ©. The clothes that the night had wet, the next dayâ€™s sunshine dried upon him; and so, day after day, and night after night; he went no more beneath the planks; whatever he wanted from the cabin that thing he sent for.

He ate in the same open air; that is, his two only meals,â€”breakfast and dinner: supper he never touched; nor reaped his beard; which darkly grew all gnarled, as unearthed roots of trees blown over, which still grow idly on at naked base, though perished in the upper verdure. But though his whole life was now become one watch on deck; and though the Parseeâ€™s mystic watch was without intermission as his own; yet these two never seemed to speakâ€”one man to the otherâ€”unless at long intervals some passing unmomentous matter made it necessary. Though such a potent spell seemed secretly to join the twain; openly, and to the awe-struck crew, they seemed pole-like asunder. If by day they chanced to speak one word; by night, dumb men were both, so far as concerned the slightest verbal interchange. At times, for longest hours, without a single hail, they stood far parted in the starlight; Ahab in his scuttle, the Parsee by the mainmast; but still fixedly gazing upon each other; as if in the Parsee Ahab saw his forethrown shadow, in Ahab the Parsee his abandoned substance.

And yet, somehow, did Ahabâ€”in his own proper self, as daily, hourly, and every instant, commandingly revealed to his subordinates,â€”Ahab seemed an independent lord; the Parsee but his slave. Still again both seemed yoked together, and an unseen tyrant driving them; the lean shade siding the solid rib. For be this Parsee what he may, all rib and keel was solid Ahab.

At the first faintest glimmering of the dawn, his iron voice was heard from aft,â€”â€œMan the mast-heads!â€â€”and all through the day, till after ğŸŒ‡ and after twilight, the same voice every hour, at the striking of the helmsmanâ€™s bell, was heardâ€”â€œWhat dâ€™ye see?â€”sharp! sharp!â€

But when three or four days had slided by, after meeting the children-seeking Rachel; and no spout had yet been seen; the monomaniac old man seemed distrustful of his crewâ€™s fidelity; at least, of nearly all except the Pagan harpooneers; he seemed to doubt, even, whether Stubb and Flask might not willingly overlook the sight he sought. But if these suspicions were really his, he sagaciously refrained from verbally expressing them, however his actions might seem to hint them.

â€œI will have the first sight of the ğŸ‹ myself,â€â€”he said. â€œAye! Ahab must have the doubloon!â€ and with his ownâœ‹s he rigged a nest of basketed bowlines; and sending aâœ‹ aloft, with a single sheaved block, to secure to the main-mast head, he received the two ends of the downward-reeved rope; and attaching one to his basket prepared a pin for the other end, in order to fasten it at the rail. This done, with that end yet in hisâœ‹ and standing beside the pin, he looked round upon his crew, sweeping from one to the other; pausing his glance long upon Daggoo, Queequeg, Tashtego; but shunning Fedallah; and then settling his firm relying eye upon the chief mate, said,â€”â€œTake the rope, sirâ€”I give it into thyâœ‹s, â­ğŸ’².â€ Then arranging his person in the basket, he gave the word for them to hoist him to his perch, â­ğŸ’² being the one who secured the rope at last; and afterwards stood near it. And thus, with oneâœ‹ clinging round the royal mast, Ahab gazed abroad upon the sea for miles and miles,â€”ahead, astern, this side, and that,â€”within the wide expanded circle commanded at so great a height.

When in working with hisâœ‹s at some lofty almost isolated place in the rigging, which chances to afford no foothold, the sailor at sea is hoisted up to that spot, and sustained there by the rope; under these circumstances, its fastened end on deck is always given in strict charge to some one man who has the special watch of it. Because in such a wilderness of running rigging, whose various different relations aloft cannot always be infallibly discerned by what is seen of them at the deck; and when the deck-ends of these ropes are being every few minutes cast down from the fastenings, it would be but a natural fatality, if, unprovided with a constant watchman, the hoisted sailor should by some carelessness of the crew be cast adrift and fall all swooping to the sea. So Ahabâ€™s proceedings in this matter were not unusual; the only strange thing about them seemed to be, that â­ğŸ’², almost the one only man who had ever ventured to oppose him with anything in the slightest degree approaching to decisionâ€”one of those too, whose faithfulness on the look-out he had seemed to doubt somewhat;â€”it was strange, that this was the very man he should select for his watchman; freely giving his whole life into such an otherwise distrusted personâ€™sâœ‹s.

Now, the first time Ahab was perched aloft; ere he had been there ten minutes; one of those red-billed savage sea-hawks which so often fly incommodiously close round the manned mast-heads of ğŸ‹men in these latitudes; one of these birds came wheeling and screaming round his head in a maze of untrackably swift circlings. Then it darted a thousand feet straight up into the air; then spiralized downwards, and went eddying again round his head.

But with his gaze fixed upon the dim and distant horizon, Ahab seemed not to mark this wild bird; nor, indeed, would any one else have marked it much, it being no uncommon circumstance; only now almost the least heedful eye seemed to see some sort of cunning meaning in almost every sight.

â€œYour ğŸ©, your ğŸ©, sir!â€ suddenly cried the Sicilian seaman, who being posted at the mizen-mast-head, stood directly behind Ahab, though somewhat lower than his level, and with a deep gulf of air dividing them.

But already the sable wing was before the old manâ€™s ğŸ‘€; the long hooked bill at his head: with a scream, the black hawk darted away with his prize.

An eagle flew thrice round Tarquinâ€™s head, removing his cap to replace it, and thereupon Tanaquil, his wife, declared that Tarquin would be king of Rome. But only by the replacing of the cap was that omen accounted good. Ahabâ€™s hat was never restored; the wild hawk flew on and on with it; far in advance of the prow: and at last disappeared; while from the point of that disappearance, a minute black spot was dimly discerned, falling from that vast height into the sea.





CHAPTER 131. The Pequod Meets The Delight.

The intense Pequod sailed on; the rolling ğŸŒŠ and days went by; the life-buoy-âš°ï¸ still lightly swung; and anotherğŸš¢, most miserably misnamed the Delight, was descried. As she drew nigh, all ğŸ‘€ were fixed upon her broad beams, called shears, which, in some whaling-ships, cross the quarter-deck at the height of eight or nine feet; serving to carry the spare, unrigged, or disabled â›µs.

Upon the strangerâ€™s shears were beheld the shattered, â¬œ ribs, and some few splintered planks, of what had once been a ğŸ‹-â›µ; but you now saw through this wreck, as plainly as you see through the peeled, half-unhinged, and bleaching skeleton of a horse.

â€œHast seen the â¬œ ğŸ‹?â€

â€œLook!â€ replied the hollow-cheeked captain from his taffrail; and with his trumpet he pointed to the wreck.

â€œHast killed him?â€

â€œThe harpoon is not yet forged that ever will do that,â€ answered the other, sadly glancing upon a rounded hammock on the deck, whose gathered sides some noiseless sailors were busy in sewing together.

â€œNot forged!â€ and snatching Perthâ€™s levelled iron from the crotch, Ahab held it out, exclaimingâ€”â€œLook ye, Nantucketer; here in thisâœ‹ I hold his ğŸ’€! Tempered in blood, and tempered by âš¡ are these barbs; and I swear to temper them triply in that hot place behind the fin, where the â¬œ ğŸ‹ most feels his accursed life!â€

â€œThen God keep thee, old manâ€”seeâ€™st thou thatâ€â€”pointing to the hammockâ€”â€œI bury but one of five stout men, who were alive only yesterday; but were dead ere night. Only that one I bury; the rest were buried before they died; you sail upon their tomb.â€ Then turning to his crewâ€”â€œAre ye ready there? place the plank then on the rail, and lift the body; so, thenâ€”Oh! Godâ€â€”advancing towards the hammock with upliftedâœ‹sâ€”â€œmay the resurrection and the lifeâ€”â€”â€

â€œBrace forward! Up helm!â€ cried Ahab like âš¡ to his men.

But the suddenly started Pequod was not quick enough to escape the sound of the splash that the corpse soon made as it struck the sea; not so quick, indeed, but that some of the flying bubbles might have sprinkled her hull with their ghostly baptism.

As Ahab now glided from the dejected Delight, the strange life-buoy hanging at the Pequodâ€™s stern came into conspicuous relief.

â€œHa! yonder! look yonder, men!â€ cried a foreboding voice in her wake. â€œIn vain, oh, ye strangers, ye fly our sad burial; ye but turn us your taffrail to show us your âš°ï¸!â€





CHAPTER 132. The Symphony.

It was a clear steel-blue day. The firmaments of air and sea were hardly separable in that all-pervading azure; only, the pensive air was transparently pure and soft, with a womanâ€™s look, and the robust and man-like sea heaved with long, strong, lingering swells, as Samsonâ€™s chest in his sleep.

Hither, and thither, on high, glided the â„ï¸-â¬œ wings of small, unspeckled birds; these were the gentle thoughts of the feminine air; but to and fro in the deeps, far down in the bottomless blue, rushed mighty leviathans, ğŸ—¡ï¸-ğŸŸ, and ğŸ¦ˆs; and these were the strong, troubled, murderous thinkings of the masculine sea.

But though thus contrasting within, the contrast was only in shades and shadows without; those two seemed one; it was only the sex, as it were, that distinguished them.

Aloft, like a royal czar and king, the sun seemed giving this gentle air to this bold and rolling sea; even as bride to groom. And at the girdling line of the horizon, a soft and tremulous motionâ€”most seen here at the equatorâ€”denoted the fond, throbbing trust, the loving alarms, with which the poor bride gave her bosom away.

Tied up and twisted; gnarled and knotted with wrinkles; haggardly firm and unyielding; his ğŸ‘€ glowing like coals, that still glow in the ashes of ruin; untottering Ahab stood forth in the clearness of the morn; lifting his splintered helmet of a brow to the fair girlâ€™s forehead of heaven.

Oh, immortal infancy, and innocency of the azure! Invisible winged creatures that frolic all round us! Sweet childhood of air and sky! how oblivious were ye of old Ahabâ€™s close-coiled woe! But so have I seen little Miriam and Martha, laughing-eyed elves, heedlessly gambol around their old sire; sporting with the circle of singed locks which grew on the marge of that burnt-out crater of his brain.

Slowly crossing the deck from the scuttle, Ahab leaned over the side and watched how his shadow in the water sank and sank to his gaze, the more and the more that he strove to pierce the profundity. But the lovely aromas in that enchanted air did at last seem to dispel, for a moment, the cankerous thing in his soul. That glad, happy air, that winsome sky, did at last stroke and caress him; the step-mother world, so long cruelâ€”forbiddingâ€”now threw affectionateğŸ’ªs round his stubborn neck, and did seem to joyously sob over him, as if over one, that however wilful and erring, she could yet find it in her â¤ï¸ to save and to bless. From beneath his slouched hat Ahab dropped a tear into the sea; nor did all the Pacific contain such wealth as that one wee drop.

â­ğŸ’² saw the old man; saw him, how he heavily leaned over the side; and he seemed to hear in his own true â¤ï¸ the measureless sobbing that stole out of the centre of the serenity around. Careful not to touch him, or be noticed by him, he yet drew near to him, and stood there.

Ahab turned.

â€œâ­ğŸ’²!â€

â€œSir.â€

â€œOh, â­ğŸ’²! it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky. On such a dayâ€”very much such a sweetness as thisâ€”I struck my first ğŸ‹â€”a boy-harpooneer of eighteen! Fortyâ€”fortyâ€”forty years ago!â€”ago! Forty years of continual whaling! forty years of privation, and peril, and â›ˆï¸-time! forty years on the pitiless sea! for forty years has Ahab forsaken the peaceful land, for forty years to make war on the horrors of the deep! Aye and yes, â­ğŸ’², out of those forty years I have not spent three ashore. When I think of this life I have led; the desolation of solitude it has been; the masoned, walled-town of a Captainâ€™s exclusiveness, which admits but small entrance to any sympathy from the green country withoutâ€”oh, weariness! heaviness! Guinea-coast slavery of solitary command!â€”when I think of all this; only half-suspected, not so keenly known to me beforeâ€”and how for forty years I have fed upon dry salted fareâ€”fit emblem of the dry nourishment of my soil!â€”when the poorest landsman has had fresh fruit to his dailyâœ‹, and broken the worldâ€™s fresh bread to my mouldy crustsâ€”away, whole oceans away, from that young girl-wife I wedded past fifty, and sailed for Cape Horn the next day, leaving but one dent in my marriage pillowâ€”wife? wife?â€”rather a widow with her husband alive! Aye, I widowed that poor girl when I married her, â­ğŸ’²; and then, the madness, the frenzy, the boiling blood and the smoking brow, with which, for a thousand lowerings old Ahab has furiously, foamingly chased his preyâ€”more a demon than a man!â€”aye, aye! what a forty yearsâ€™ foolâ€”foolâ€”old fool, has old Ahab been! Why this strife of the chase? why weary, and palsy theğŸ’ª at the oar, and the iron, and the lance? how the richer or better is Ahab now? Behold. Oh, â­ğŸ’²! is it not hard, that with this weary load I bear, one poorğŸ¦µ should have been snatched from under me? Here, brush this old hair aside; it blinds me, that I seem to weep. Locks so grey did never grow but from out some ashes! But do I look very old, so very, very old, â­ğŸ’²? I feel deadly faint, bowed, and humped, as though I were Adam, staggering beneath the piled centuries since Paradise. God! God! God!â€”crack my â¤ï¸ !â€”stave my brain!â€”mockery! mockery! bitter, biting mockery of grey hairs, have I lived enough joy to wear ye; and seem and feel thus intolerably old? Close! stand close to me, â­ğŸ’²; let me look into a human eye; it is better than to gaze into sea or sky; better than to gaze upon God. By the green land; by the bright â¤ï¸ h-stone! this is the magic glass, man; I see my wife and my child in thine eye. No, no; stay on board, on board!â€”lower not when I do; when branded Ahab gives chase to ğŸ³. That hazard shall not be thine. No, no! not with the far away home I see in that eye!â€

â€œOh, my Captain! my Captain! noble soul! grand old â¤ï¸ , after all! why should any one give chase to that hated ğŸŸ! Away with me! let us fly these deadly waters! let us home! Wife and child, too, are â­ğŸ’²â€™sâ€”wife and child of his brotherly, sisterly, play-fellow youth; even as thine, sir, are the wife and child of thy loving, longing, paternal old age! Away! let us away!â€”this instant let me alter the course! How cheerily, how hilariously, O my Captain, would we bowl on our way to see old Nantucket again! I think, sir, they have some such mild blue days, even as this, in Nantucket.â€

â€œThey have, they have. I have seen themâ€”some summer days in the morning. About this timeâ€”yes, it is his noon nap nowâ€”the boy vivaciously wakes; sits up in ğŸ›ï¸; and his mother tells him of me, of cannibal old me; how I am abroad upon the deep, but will yet come back to dance him again.â€

â€œâ€™Tis my Mary, my Mary herself! She promised that my boy, every morning, should be carried to the hill to catch the first glimpse of his fatherâ€™s sail! Yes, yes! no more! it is done! we head for Nantucket! Come, my Captain, study out the course, and let us away! See, see! the boyâ€™s face from the window! the boyâ€™sâœ‹ on the hill!â€

But Ahabâ€™s glance was averted; like a blighted fruit tree he shook, and cast his last, cindered ğŸ to the soil.

â€œWhat is it, what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it; what cozening, hidden lord and master, and cruel, remorseless emperor commands me; that against all natural lovings and longings, I so keep pushing, and crowding, and jamming myself on all the time; recklessly making me ready to do what in my own proper, natural â¤ï¸ , I durst not so much as dare? Is Ahab, Ahab? Is it I, God, or who, that lifts thisğŸ’ª? But if the great sun move not of himself; but is as an errand-boy in heaven; nor one single star can revolve, but by some invisible power; how then can this one small â¤ï¸ beat; this one small brain think thoughts; unless God does that beating, does that thinking, does that living, and not I. By heaven, man, we are turned round and round in this world, like yonder windlass, and Fate is theâœ‹spike. And all the time, lo! that smiling sky, and this unsounded sea! Look! see yon Albicore! who put it into him to chase and fang that flying-ğŸŸ? Where do murderers go, man! Whoâ€™s to doom, when the judge himself is dragged to the bar? But it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky; and the air smells now, as if it blew from a far-away meadow; they have been making hay somewhere under the slopes of the Andes, â­ğŸ’², and the mowers are sleeping among the new-mown hay. Sleeping? Aye, toil we how we may, we all sleep at last on the field. Sleep? Aye, and rust amid greenness; as last yearâ€™s scythes flung down, and left in the half-cut swathsâ€”â­ğŸ’²!â€

But blanched to a corpseâ€™s hue with despair, the Mate had stolen away.

Ahab crossed the deck to gaze over on the other side; but started at two reflected, fixed ğŸ‘€ in the water there. Fedallah was motionlessly leaning over the same rail.





CHAPTER 133. The Chaseâ€”First Day.

That night, in the mid-watch, when the old manâ€”as his wont at intervalsâ€”stepped forth from the scuttle in which he leaned, and went to his pivot-hole, he suddenly thrust out his face fiercely, snuffing up the sea air as a sagaciousğŸš¢â€™s dog will, in drawing nigh to some barbarous isle. He declared that a ğŸ‹ must be near. Soon that peculiar odor, sometimes to a great distance given forth by the living sperm ğŸ‹, was palpable to all the watch; nor was any mariner surprised when, after inspecting the compass, and then the dog-vane, and then ascertaining the precise bearing of the odor as nearly as possible, Ahab rapidly ordered theğŸš¢â€™s course to be slightly altered, and the sail to be shortened.

The acute policy dictating these movements was sufficiently vindicated at daybreak, by the sight of a long sleek on the sea directly and lengthwise ahead, smooth as oil, and resembling in the pleated watery wrinkles bordering it, the polished metallic-like marks of some swift tide-rip, at the mouth of a deep, rapid stream.

â€œMan the mast-heads! Call allâœ‹s!â€

Thundering with the butts of three clubbedâœ‹spikes on the forecastle deck, Daggoo roused the sleepers with such judgment claps that they seemed to exhale from the scuttle, so instantaneously did they appear with their clothes in theirâœ‹s.

â€œWhat dâ€™ye see?â€ cried Ahab, flattening his face to the sky.

â€œNothing, nothing sir!â€ was the sound hailing down in reply.

â€œTâ€™gallant sails!â€”stunsails! alow and aloft, and on both sides!â€

All sail being set, he now cast loose the life-line, reserved for swaying him to the main royal-mast head; and in a few moments they were hoisting him thither, when, while but two thirds of the way aloft, and while peering ahead through the horizontal vacancy between the main-top-sail and top-gallant-sail, he raised a gull-like cry in the air. â€œThere she blows!â€”there she blows! A hump like a â„ï¸-hill! It is ğŸ³!â€

ğŸ”¥d by the cry which seemed simultaneously taken up by the three look-outs, the men on deck rushed to the rigging to behold the famous ğŸ‹ they had so long been pursuing. Ahab had now gained his final perch, some feet above the other look-outs, Tashtego standing just beneath him on the cap of the top-gallant-mast, so that the Indianâ€™s head was almost on a level with Ahabâ€™s heel. From this height the ğŸ‹ was now seen some mile or so ahead, at every roll of the sea revealing his high sparkling hump, and regularly jetting his silent spout into the air. To the credulous mariners it seemed the same silent spout they had so long ago beheld in the ğŸŒ•lit Atlantic and Indian Oceans.

â€œAnd did none of ye see it before?â€ cried Ahab, hailing the perched men all around him.

â€œI saw him almost that same instant, sir, that Captain Ahab did, and I cried out,â€ said Tashtego.

â€œNot the same instant; not the sameâ€”no, the doubloon is mine, Fate reserved the doubloon for me. I only; none of ye could have raised the â¬œ ğŸ‹ first. There she blows!â€”there she blows!â€”there she blows! There again!â€”there again!â€ he cried, in long-drawn, lingering, methodic tones, attuned to the gradual prolongings of the ğŸ‹â€™s visible jets. â€œHeâ€™s going to sound! In stunsails! Down top-gallant-sails! Stand by three â›µs. Mr. â­ğŸ’², remember, stay on board, and keep theğŸš¢. Helm there! Luff, luff a point! So; steady, man, steady! There go flukes! No, no; only black water! All ready the â›µs there? Stand by, stand by! Lower me, Mr. â­ğŸ’²; lower, lower,â€”quick, quicker!â€ and he slid through the air to the deck.

â€œHe is heading straight to leeward, sir,â€ cried Stubb, â€œright away from us; cannot have seen theğŸš¢ yet.â€

â€œBe dumb, man! Stand by the braces! Hard down the helm!â€”brace up! Shiver her!â€”shiver her!â€”So; well that! â›µs, â›µs!â€

Soon all the â›µs but â­ğŸ’²â€™s were dropped; all the â›µ-sails setâ€”all the paddles plying; with rippling swiftness, shooting to leeward; and Ahab heading the onset. A pale, ğŸ’€-glimmer lit up Fedallahâ€™s sunken ğŸ‘€; a hideous motion gnawed his mouth.

Like noiseless nautilus shells, their light prows sped through the sea; but only slowly they neared the foe. As they neared him, the ocean grew still more smooth; seemed drawing a carpet over its ğŸŒŠ; seemed a noon-meadow, so serenely it spread. At length the breathless hunter came so nigh his seemingly unsuspecting prey, that his entire dazzling hump was distinctly visible, sliding along the sea as if an isolated thing, and continually set in a revolving ring of finest, fleecy, greenish foam. He saw the vast, involved wrinkles of the slightly projecting head beyond. Before it, far out on the soft Turkish-rugged waters, went the glistening â¬œ shadow from his broad, milky forehead, a musical rippling playfully accompanying the shade; and behind, the blue waters interchangeably flowed over into the moving valley of his steady wake; and on eitherâœ‹ bright bubbles arose and danced by his side. But these were broken again by the light toes of hundreds of gay fowl softly feathering the sea, alternate with their fitful flight; and like to some flag-staff rising from the painted hull of an argosy, the tall but shattered pole of a recent lance projected from the â¬œ ğŸ‹â€™s back; and at intervals one of the cloud of soft-toed fowls hovering, and to and fro skimming like a canopy over the ğŸŸ, silently perched and rocked on this pole, the long tail feathers streaming like pennons.

A gentle joyousnessâ€”a mighty mildness of repose in swiftness, invested the gliding ğŸ‹. Not the â¬œ bull Jupiter swimming away with ravished Europa clinging to his graceful horns; his lovely, leering ğŸ‘€ sideways intent upon the maid; with smooth bewitching fleetness, rippling straight for the nuptial bower in Crete; not Jove, not that great majesty Supreme! did surpass the glorified â¬œ ğŸ‹ as he so divinely swam.

On each soft sideâ€”coincident with the parted swell, that but once leaving him, then flowed so wide awayâ€”on each bright side, the ğŸ‹ shed off enticings. No wonder there had been some among the hunters who namelessly transported and allured by all this serenity, had ventured to assail it; but had fatally found that quietude but the vesture of tornadoes. Yet calm, enticing calm, oh, ğŸ‹! thou glidest on, to all who for the first time eye thee, no matter how many in that same way thou mayâ€™st have bejuggled and destroyed before.

And thus, through the serene tranquillities of the tropical sea, among ğŸŒŠ whoseâœ‹-clappings were suspended by exceeding rapture, ğŸ³ moved on, still withholding from sight the full terrors of his submerged trunk, entirely hiding the wrenched hideousness of his jaw. But soon the fore part of him slowly rose from the water; for an instant his whole marbleized body formed a high arch, like Virginiaâ€™s Natural Bridge, and warningly waving his bannered flukes in the air, the grand god revealed himself, sounded, and went out of sight. Hoveringly halting, and dipping on the wing, the â¬œ sea-fowls longingly lingered over the agitated pool that he left.

With oars apeak, and paddles down, the sheets of their sails adrift, the three â›µs now stilly floated, awaiting ğŸ³â€™s reappearance.

â€œAn hour,â€ said Ahab, standing rooted in his â›µâ€™s stern; and he gazed beyond the ğŸ‹â€™s place, towards the dim blue spaces and wide wooing vacancies to leeward. It was only an instant; for again his ğŸ‘€ seemed whirling round in his head as he swept the watery circle. The breeze now freshened; the sea began to swell.

â€œThe birds!â€”the birds!â€ cried Tashtego.

In long Indian file, as when herons take wing, the â¬œ birds were now all flying towards Ahabâ€™s â›µ; and when within a few yards began fluttering over the water there, wheeling round and round, with joyous, expectant cries. Their vision was keener than manâ€™s; Ahab could discover no sign in the sea. But suddenly as he peered down and down into its depths, he profoundly saw a â¬œ living spot no bigger than a â¬œ weasel, with wonderful celerity uprising, and magnifying as it rose, till it turned, and then there were plainly revealed two long crooked rows of â¬œ, glistening teeth, floating up from the undiscoverable bottom. It was ğŸ³â€™s open mouth and scrolled jaw; his vast, shadowed bulk still half blending with the blue of the sea. The glittering mouth yawned beneath the â›µ like an open-doored marble tomb; and giving one sidelong sweep with his steering oar, Ahab whirled the craft aside from this tremendous apparition. Then, calling upon Fedallah to change places with him, went forward to the bows, and seizing Perthâ€™s harpoon, commanded his crew to grasp their oars and stand by to stern.

Now, by reason of this timely spinning round the â›µ upon its axis, its bow, by anticipation, was made to face the ğŸ‹â€™s head while yet under water. But as if perceiving this stratagem, ğŸ³, with that malicious intelligence ascribed to him, sidelingly transplanted himself, as it were, in an instant, shooting his pleated head lengthwise beneath the â›µ.

Through and through; through every plank and each rib, it thrilled for an instant, the ğŸ‹ obliquely lying on his back, in the manner of a biting ğŸ¦ˆ, slowly and feelingly taking its bows full within his mouth, so that the long, narrow, scrolled lower jaw curled high up into the open air, and one of the teeth caught in a row-lock. The bluish pearl-â¬œ of the inside of the jaw was within six inches of Ahabâ€™s head, and reached higher than that. In this attitude the â¬œ ğŸ‹ now shook the slight cedar as a mildly cruel cat her mouse. With unastonished ğŸ‘€ Fedallah gazed, and crossed hisğŸ’ªs; but the tiger-yellow crew were tumbling over each otherâ€™s heads to gain the uttermost stern.

And now, while both elastic gunwales were springing in and out, as the ğŸ‹ dallied with the doomed craft in this ğŸ‘¿ish way; and from his body being submerged beneath the â›µ, he could not be darted at from the bows, for the bows were almost inside of him, as it were; and while the other â›µs involuntarily paused, as before a quick crisis impossible to withstand, then it was that monomaniac Ahab, furious with this tantalizing vicinity of his foe, which placed him all alive and helpless in the very jaws he hated; frenzied with all this, he seized the long bone with his nakedâœ‹s, and wildly strove to wrench it from its gripe. As now he thus vainly strove, the jaw slipped from him; the frail gunwales bent in, collapsed, and snapped, as both jaws, like an enormous shears, sliding further aft, bit the craft completely in twain, and locked themselves fast again in the sea, midway between the two floating wrecks. These floated aside, the broken ends drooping, the crew at the stern-wreck clinging to the gunwales, and striving to hold fast to the oars to lash them across.

At that preluding moment, ere the â›µ was yet snapped, Ahab, the first to perceive the ğŸ‹â€™s intent, by the crafty upraising of his head, a movement that loosed his hold for the time; at that moment hisâœ‹ had made one final effort to push the â›µ out of the bite. But only slipping further into the ğŸ‹â€™s mouth, and tilting over sideways as it slipped, the â›µ had shaken off his hold on the jaw; spilled him out of it, as he leaned to the push; and so he fell flat-faced upon the sea.

Ripplingly withdrawing from his prey, ğŸ³ now lay at a little distance, vertically thrusting his oblong â¬œ head up and down in the billows; and at the same time slowly revolving his whole spindled body; so that when his vast wrinkled forehead roseâ€”some twenty or more feet out of the waterâ€”the now rising swells, with all their confluent ğŸŒŠ, dazzlingly broke against it; vindictively tossing their shivered spray still higher into the air.* So, in a gale, the but half baffled Channel billows only recoil from the base of the Eddystone, triumphantly to overleap its summit with their scud.

*This motion is peculiar to the sperm ğŸ‹. It receives its designation (pitchpoling) from its being likened to that preliminary up-and-down poise of the ğŸ‹-lance, in the exercise called pitchpoling, previously described. By this motion the ğŸ‹ must best and most comprehensively view whatever objects may be encircling him.

But soon resuming his horizontal attitude, ğŸ³ swam swiftly round and round the wrecked crew; sideways churning the water in his vengeful wake, as if lashing himself up to still another and more deadly assault. The sight of the splintered â›µ seemed to madden him, as the blood of grapes and mulberries cast before Antiochusâ€™s ğŸ˜s in the ğŸ“˜ of Maccabees. Meanwhile Ahab half smothered in the foam of the ğŸ‹â€™s insolent tail, and too much of a cripple to swim,â€”though he could still keep afloat, even in the â¤ï¸ of such a whirlpool as that; helpless Ahabâ€™s head was seen, like a tossed bubble which the least chance shock might burst. From the â›µâ€™s fragmentary stern, Fedallah incuriously and mildly eyed him; the clinging crew, at the other drifting end, could not succor him; more than enough was it for them to look to themselves. For so revolvingly appalling was the â¬œ ğŸ‹â€™s aspect, and so planetarily swift the ever-contracting circles he made, that he seemed horizontally swooping upon them. And though the other â›µs, unharmed, still hovered hard by; still they dared not pull into the eddy to strike, lest that should be the signal for the instant destruction of the jeopardized castaways, Ahab and all; nor in that case could they themselves hope to escape. With straining ğŸ‘€, then, they remained on the outer edge of the direful zone, whose centre had now become the old manâ€™s head.

Meantime, from the beginning all this had been descried from theğŸš¢â€™s mast heads; and squaring her yards, she had borne down upon the scene; and was now so nigh, that Ahab in the water hailed her!â€”â€œSail on theâ€â€”but that moment a breaking sea dashed on him from ğŸ³, and whelmed him for the time. But struggling out of it again, and chancing to rise on a towering crest, he shouted,â€”â€œSail on the ğŸ‹!â€”Drive him off!â€

The Pequodâ€™s prows were pointed; and breaking up the charmed circle, she effectually parted the â¬œ ğŸ‹ from his victim. As he sullenly swam off, the â›µs flew to the rescue.

Dragged into Stubbâ€™s â›µ with blood-shot, blinded ğŸ‘€, the â¬œ brine caking in his wrinkles; the long tension of Ahabâ€™s bodily strength did crack, and helplessly he yielded to his bodyâ€™s doom: for a time, lying all crushed in the bottom of Stubbâ€™s â›µ, like one trodden under foot of herds of ğŸ˜s. Far inland, nameless wails came from him, as desolate sounds from out ravines.

But this intensity of his physical prostration did but so much the more abbreviate it. In an instantâ€™s compass, great â¤ï¸ s sometimes condense to one deep pang, the sum total of those shallow pains kindly diffused through feebler menâ€™s whole lives. And so, such â¤ï¸ s, though summary in each one suffering; still, if the gods decree it, in their life-time aggregate a whole age of woe, wholly made up of instantaneous intensities; for even in their pointless centres, those noble natures contain the entire circumferences of inferior souls.

â€œThe harpoon,â€ said Ahab, half way rising, and draggingly leaning on one bendedğŸ’ªâ€”â€œis it safe?â€

â€œAye, sir, for it was not darted; this is it,â€ said Stubb, showing it.

â€œLay it before me;â€”any missing men?â€

â€œOne, two, three, four, five;â€”there were five oars, sir, and here are five men.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good.â€”Help me, man; I wish to stand. So, so, I see him! there! there! going to leeward still; what a leaping spout!â€”Hands off from me! The eternal sap runs up in Ahabâ€™s bones again! Set the sail; out oars; the helm!â€

It is often the case that when a â›µ is stove, its crew, being picked up by another â›µ, help to work that second â›µ; and the chase is thus continued with what is called double-banked oars. It was thus now. But the added power of the â›µ did not equal the added power of the ğŸ‹, for he seemed to have treble-banked his every fin; swimming with a velocity which plainly showed, that if now, under these circumstances, pushed on, the chase would prove an indefinitely prolonged, if not a hopeless one; nor could any crew endure for so long a period, such an unintermitted, intense straining at the oar; a thing barely tolerable only in some one brief vicissitude. TheğŸš¢ itself, then, as it sometimes happens, offered the most promising intermediate means of overtaking the chase. Accordingly, the â›µs now made for her, and were soon swayed up to their cranesâ€”the two parts of the wrecked â›µ having been previously secured by herâ€”and then hoisting everything to her side, and stacking her canvas high up, and sideways outstretching it with stun-sails, like the double-jointed wings of an albatross; the Pequod bore down in the leeward wake of ğŸ³. At the well known, methodic intervals, the ğŸ‹â€™s glittering spout was regularly announced from the manned mast-heads; and when he would be reported as just gone down, Ahab would take the time, and then pacing the deck, binnacle-watch inâœ‹, so soon as the last second of the allotted hour expired, his voice was heard.â€”â€œWhose is the doubloon now? Dâ€™ye see him?â€ and if the reply was, No, sir! straightway he commanded them to lift him to his perch. In this way the day wore on; Ahab, now aloft and motionless; anon, unrestingly pacing the planks.

As he was thus walking, uttering no sound, except to hail the men aloft, or to bid them hoist a sail still higher, or to spread one to a still greater breadthâ€”thus to and fro pacing, beneath his slouched ğŸ©, at every turn he passed his own wrecked â›µ, which had been dropped upon the quarter-deck, and lay there reversed; broken bow to shattered stern. At last he paused before it; and as in an already over-clouded sky fresh troops of clouds will sometimes sail across, so over the old manâ€™s face there now stole some such added gloom as this.

Stubb saw him pause; and perhaps intending, not vainly, though, to evince his own unabated fortitude, and thus keep up a valiant place in his Captainâ€™s mind, he advanced, and eyeing the wreck exclaimedâ€”â€œThe thistle the ass refused; it pricked his mouth too keenly, sir; ha! ha!â€

â€œWhat soulless thing is this that laughs before a wreck? Man, man! did I not know thee brave as fearless ğŸ”¥ (and as mechanical) I could swear thou wert a poltroon. Groan nor laugh should be heard before a wreck.â€

â€œAye, sir,â€ said â­ğŸ’² drawing near, â€œâ€™tis a solemn sight; an omen, and an ill one.â€

â€œOmen? omen?â€”the dictionary! If the gods think to speak outright to man, they will honorably speak outright; not shake their heads, and give an old wivesâ€™ darkling hint.â€”Begone! Ye two are the opposite poles of one thing; â­ğŸ’² is Stubb reversed, and Stubb is â­ğŸ’²; and ye two are all mankind; and Ahab stands alone among the millions of the peopled earth, nor gods nor men his neighbors! Cold, coldâ€”I shiver!â€”How now? Aloft there! Dâ€™ye see him? Sing out for every spout, though he spout ten times a second!â€

The day was nearly done; only the hem of his golden robe was rustling. Soon, it was almost dark, but the look-out men still remained unset.

â€œCanâ€™t see the spout now, sir;â€”too darkâ€â€”cried a voice from the air.

â€œHow heading when last seen?â€

â€œAs before, sir,â€”straight to leeward.â€

â€œGood! he will travel slower now â€™tis night. Down royals and top-gallant stun-sails, Mr. â­ğŸ’². We must not run over him before morning; heâ€™s making a passage now, and may heave-to a while. Helm there! keep her full before the wind!â€”Aloft! come down!â€”Mr. Stubb, send a freshâœ‹ to the fore-mast head, and see it manned till morning.â€â€”Then advancing towards the doubloon in the main-mastâ€”â€œMen, this gold is mine, for I earned it; but I shall let it abide here till the â¬œ ğŸ‹ is dead; and then, whosoever of ye first raises him, upon the day he shall be killed, this gold is that manâ€™s; and if on that day I shall again raise him, then, ten times its sum shall be divided among all of ye! Away now!â€”the deck is thine, sir!â€

And so saying, he placed himself half way within the scuttle, and slouching his ğŸ©, stood there till dawn, except when at intervals rousing himself to see how the night wore on.





CHAPTER 134. The Chaseâ€”Second Day.

At day-break, the three mast-heads were punctually manned afresh.

â€œDâ€™ye see him?â€ cried Ahab after allowing a little space for the light to spread.

â€œSee nothing, sir.â€

â€œTurn up allâœ‹s and make sail! he travels faster than I thought for;â€”the top-gallant sails!â€”aye, they should have been kept on her all night. But no matterâ€”â€™tis but resting for the rush.â€

Here be it said, that this pertinacious pursuit of one particular ğŸ‹, continued through day into night, and through night into day, is a thing by no means unprecedented in the South sea ğŸŸery. For such is the wonderful skill, prescience of experience, and invincible confidence acquired by some great natural geniuses among the Nantucket commanders; that from the simple observation of a ğŸ‹ when last descried, they will, under certain given circumstances, pretty accurately foretell both the direction in which he will continue to swim for a time, while out of sight, as well as his probable rate of progression during that period. And, in these cases, somewhat as a pilot, when about losing sight of a coast, whose general trending he well knows, and which he desires shortly to return to again, but at some further point; like as this pilot stands by his compass, and takes the precise bearing of the cape at present visible, in order the more certainly to hit aright the remote, unseen headland, eventually to be visited: so does the ğŸŸerman, at his compass, with the ğŸ‹; for after being chased, and diligently marked, through several hours of daylight, then, when night obscures the ğŸŸ, the creatureâ€™s future wake through the darkness is almost as established to the sagacious mind of the hunter, as the pilotâ€™s coast is to him. So that to this hunterâ€™s wondrous skill, the proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in water, a wake, is to all desired purposes well nigh as reliable as the steadfast land. And as the mighty iron Leviathan of the modern railway is so familiarly known in its every pace, that, with watches in theirâœ‹s, men time his rate as doctors that of a babyâ€™s pulse; and lightly say of it, the up train or the down train will reach such or such a spot, at such or such an hour; even so, almost, there are occasions when these Nantucketers time that other Leviathan of the deep, according to the observed humor of his speed; and say to themselves, so many hours hence this ğŸ‹ will have gone two hundred miles, will have about reached this or that degree of latitude or longitude. But to render this acuteness at all successful in the end, the wind and the sea must be the ğŸ‹manâ€™s allies; for of what present avail to the becalmed or windbound mariner is the skill that assures him he is exactly ninety-three leagues and a quarter from his port? Inferable from these statements, are many collateral subtile matters touching the chase of ğŸ‹s.

TheğŸš¢ tore on; leaving such a furrow in the sea as when a cannon-ball, missent, becomes a plough-share and turns up the level field.

â€œBy salt and hemp!â€ cried Stubb, â€œbut this swift motion of the deck creeps up oneâ€™sğŸ¦µs and tingles at the â¤ï¸ . ThisğŸš¢ and I are two brave fellows!â€”Ha, ha! Some one take me up, and launch me, spine-wise, on the sea,â€”for by live-oaks! my spineâ€™s a keel. Ha, ha! we go the gait that leaves no dust behind!â€

â€œThere she blowsâ€”she blows!â€”she blows!â€”right ahead!â€ was now the mast-head cry.

â€œAye, aye!â€ cried Stubb, â€œI knew itâ€”ye canâ€™t escapeâ€”blow on and split your spout, O ğŸ‹! the mad fiend himself is after ye! blow your trumpâ€”blister your lungs!â€”Ahab will dam off your blood, as a miller shuts his watergate upon the stream!â€

And Stubb did but speak out for well nigh all that crew. The frenzies of the chase had by this time worked them bubblingly up, like old ğŸ· worked anew. Whatever pale fears and forebodings some of them might have felt before; these were not only now kept out of sight through the growing awe of Ahab, but they were broken up, and on all sides routed, as timid prairie hares that scatter before the bounding bison. Theâœ‹ of Fate had snatched all their souls; and by the stirring perils of the previous day; the rack of the past nightâ€™s suspense; the fixed, unfearing, blind, reckless way in which their wild craft went plunging towards its flying mark; by all these things, their â¤ï¸ s were bowled along. The wind that made great bellies of their sails, and rushed the vessel on byğŸ’ªs invisible as irresistible; this seemed the symbol of that unseen agency which so enslaved them to the race.

They were one man, not thirty. For as the oneğŸš¢ that held them all; though it was put together of all contrasting thingsâ€”oak, and maple, and pine wood; iron, and pitch, and hempâ€”yet all these ran into each other in the one concrete hull, which shot on its way, both balanced and directed by the long central keel; even so, all the individualities of the crew, this manâ€™s valor, that manâ€™s fear; guilt and guiltiness, all varieties were welded into oneness, and were all directed to that fatal goal which Ahab their one lord and keel did point to.

The rigging lived. The mast-heads, like the tops of tall palms, were outspreadingly tufted withğŸ’ªs andğŸ¦µs. Clinging to a spar with oneâœ‹, some reached forth the other with impatient wavings; others, shading their ğŸ‘€ from the vivid sunlight, sat far out on the rocking yards; all the spars in full bearing of mortals, ready and ripe for their fate. Ah! how they still strove through that infinite blueness to seek out the thing that might destroy them!

â€œWhy sing ye not out for him, if ye see him?â€ cried Ahab, when, after the lapse of some minutes since the first cry, no more had been heard. â€œSway me up, men; ye have been deceived; not ğŸ³ casts one odd jet that way, and then disappears.â€

It was even so; in their headlong eagerness, the men had mistaken some other thing for the ğŸ‹-spout, as the event itself soon proved; for hardly had Ahab reached his perch; hardly was the rope belayed to its pin on deck, when he struck the key-note to an orchestra, that made the air vibrate as with the combined discharges of rifles. The triumphant halloo of thirty buckskin lungs was heard, asâ€”much nearer to theğŸš¢ than the place of the imaginary jet, less than a mile aheadâ€”ğŸ³ bodily burst into view! For not by any calm and indolent spoutings; not by the peaceable gush of that mystic fountain in his head, did the â¬œ ğŸ‹ now reveal his vicinity; but by the far more wondrous phenomenon of breaching. Rising with his utmost velocity from the furthest depths, the Sperm ğŸ‹ thus booms his entire bulk into the pure element of air, and piling up a mountain of dazzling foam, shows his place to the distance of seven miles and more. In those moments, the torn, enraged ğŸŒŠ he shakes off, seem his mane; in some cases, this breaching is his act of defiance.

â€œThere she breaches! there she breaches!â€ was the cry, as in his immeasurable bravadoes the â¬œ ğŸ‹ tossed himself salmon-like to Heaven. So suddenly seen in the blue plain of the sea, and relieved against the still bluer margin of the sky, the spray that he raised, for the moment, intolerably glittered and glared like a glacier; and stood there gradually fading and fading away from its first sparkling intensity, to the dim mistiness of an advancing shower in a vale.

â€œAye, breach your last to the sun, ğŸ³!â€ cried Ahab, â€œthy hour and thy harpoon are atâœ‹!â€”Down! down all of ye, but one man at the fore. The â›µs!â€”stand by!â€

Unmindful of the tedious rope-ladders of the shrouds, the men, like shooting stars, slid to the deck, by the isolated backstays and halyards; while Ahab, less dartingly, but still rapidly was dropped from his perch.

â€œLower away,â€ he cried, so soon as he had reached his â›µâ€”a spare one, rigged the afternoon previous. â€œMr. â­ğŸ’², theğŸš¢ is thineâ€”keep away from the â›µs, but keep near them. Lower, all!â€

As if to strike a quick terror into them, by this time being the first assailant himself, ğŸ³ had turned, and was now coming for the three crews. Ahabâ€™s â›µ was central; and cheering his men, he told them he would take the ğŸ‹ head-and-head,â€”that is, pull straight up to his forehead,â€”a not uncommon thing; for when within a certain limit, such a course excludes the coming onset from the ğŸ‹â€™s sidelong vision. But ere that close limit was gained, and while yet all three â›µs were plain as theğŸš¢â€™s three masts to his eye; the â¬œ ğŸ‹ churning himself into furious speed, almost in an instant as it were, rushing among the â›µs with open jaws, and a lashing tail, offered appalling battle on every side; and heedless of the irons darted at him from every â›µ, seemed only intent on annihilating each separate plank of which those â›µs were made. But skilfully manÅ“uvred, incessantly wheeling like trained chargers in the field; the â›µs for a while eluded him; though, at times, but by a plankâ€™s breadth; while all the time, Ahabâ€™s unearthly slogan tore every other cry but his to shreds.

But at last in his untraceable evolutions, the â¬œ ğŸ‹ so crossed and recrossed, and in a thousand ways entangled the slack of the three lines now fast to him, that they foreshortened, and, of themselves, warped the devoted â›µs towards the planted irons in him; though now for a moment the ğŸ‹ drew aside a little, as if to rally for a more tremendous charge. Seizing that opportunity, Ahab first paid out more line: and then was rapidly hauling and jerking in upon it againâ€”hoping that way to disencumber it of some snarlsâ€”when lo!â€”a sight more savage than the embattled teeth of ğŸ¦ˆs!

Caught and twistedâ€”corkscrewed in the mazes of the line, loose harpoons and lances, with all their bristling barbs and points, came flashing and dripping up to the chocks in the bows of Ahabâ€™s â›µ. Only one thing could be done. Seizing the â›µ-knife, he critically reached withinâ€”throughâ€”and then, withoutâ€”the rays of steel; dragged in the line beyond, passed it, inboard, to the bowsman, and then, twice sundering the rope near the chocksâ€”dropped the intercepted fagot of steel into the sea; and was all fast again. That instant, the â¬œ ğŸ‹ made a sudden rush among the remaining tangles of the other lines; by so doing, irresistibly dragged the more involved â›µs of Stubb and Flask towards his flukes; dashed them together like two rolling husks on a surf-beaten beach, and then, diving down into the sea, disappeared in a boiling maelstrom, in which, for a space, the odorous cedar chips of the wrecks danced round and round, like the grated nutmeg in a swiftly stirred bowl of punch.

While the two crews were yet circling in the waters, reaching out after the revolving line-tubs, oars, and other floating furniture, while aslope little Flask bobbed up and down like an empty vial, twitching hisğŸ¦µs upwards to escape the dreaded jaws of ğŸ¦ˆs; and Stubb was lustily singing out for some one to ladle him up; and while the old manâ€™s lineâ€”now partingâ€”admitted of his pulling into the creamy pool to rescue whom he could;â€”in that wild simultaneousness of a thousand concreted perils,â€”Ahabâ€™s yet unstricken â›µ seemed drawn up towards Heaven by invisible wires,â€”as, arrow-like, shooting perpendicularly from the sea, the â¬œ ğŸ‹ dashed his broad forehead against its bottom, and sent it, turning over and over, into the air; till it fell againâ€”gunwale downwardsâ€”and Ahab and his men struggled out from under it, like seals from a sea-side cave.

The first uprising momentum of the ğŸ‹â€”modifying its direction as he struck the surfaceâ€”involuntarily launched him along it, to a little distance from the centre of the destruction he had made; and with his back to it, he now lay for a moment slowly feeling with his flukes from side to side; and whenever a stray oar, bit of plank, the least chip or crumb of the â›µs touched his skin, his tail swiftly drew back, and came sideways smiting the sea. But soon, as if satisfied that his work for that time was done, he pushed his pleated forehead through the ocean, and trailing after him the intertangled lines, continued his leeward way at a travellerâ€™s methodic pace.

As before, the attentiveğŸš¢ having descried the whole fight, again came bearing down to the rescue, and dropping a â›µ, picked up the floating mariners, tubs, oars, and whatever else could be caught at, and safely landed them on her decks. Some sprained shoulders, wrists, and ankles; livid contusions; wrenched harpoons and lances; inextricable intricacies of rope; shattered oars and planks; all these were there; but no fatal or even serious ill seemed to have befallen any one. As with Fedallah the day before, so Ahab was now found grimly clinging to his â›µâ€™s broken half, which afforded a comparatively easy float; nor did it so exhaust him as the previous dayâ€™s mishap.

But when he was helped to the deck, all ğŸ‘€ were fastened upon him; as instead of standing by himself he still half-hung upon the shoulder of â­ğŸ’², who had thus far been the foremost to assist him. His ivoryğŸ¦µ had been snapped off, leaving but one short sharp splinter.

â€œAye, aye, â­ğŸ’², â€™tis sweet to lean sometimes, be the leaner who he will; and would old Ahab had leaned oftener than he has.â€

â€œThe ferrule has not stood, sir,â€ said the carpenter, now coming up; â€œI put good work into thatğŸ¦µ.â€

â€œBut no bones broken, sir, I hope,â€ said Stubb with true concern.

â€œAye! and all splintered to pieces, Stubb!â€”dâ€™ye see it.â€”But even with a broken bone, old Ahab is untouched; and I account no living bone of mine one jot more me, than this dead one thatâ€™s lost. Nor â¬œ ğŸ‹, nor man, nor fiend, can so much as graze old Ahab in his own proper and inaccessible being. Can any lead touch yonder floor, any mast scrape yonder roof?â€”Aloft there! which way?â€

â€œDead to leeward, sir.â€

â€œUp helm, then; pile on the sail again,ğŸš¢ keepers! down the rest of the spare â›µs and rig themâ€”Mr. â­ğŸ’² away, and muster the â›µâ€™s crews.â€

â€œLet me first help thee towards the bulwarks, sir.â€

â€œOh, oh, oh! how this splinter gores me now! Accursed fate! that the unconquerable captain in the soul should have such a craven mate!â€

â€œSir?â€

â€œMy body, man, not thee. Give me something for a caneâ€”there, that shivered lance will do. Muster the men. Surely I have not seen him yet. By heaven it cannot be!â€”missing?â€”quick! call them all.â€

The old manâ€™s hinted thought was true. Upon mustering the company, the Parsee was not there.

â€œThe Parsee!â€ cried Stubbâ€”â€œhe must have been caught inâ€”â€”â€

â€œThe black vomit wrench thee!â€”run all of ye above, alow, cabin, forecastleâ€”find himâ€”not goneâ€”not gone!â€

But quickly they returned to him with the tidings that the Parsee was nowhere to be found.

â€œAye, sir,â€ said Stubbâ€”â€œcaught among the tangles of your lineâ€”I thought I saw him dragging under.â€

â€œMy line! my line? Gone?â€”gone? What means that little word?â€”What ğŸ’€-knell rings in it, that old Ahab shakes as if he were the belfry. The harpoon, too!â€”toss over the litter there,â€”dâ€™ye see it?â€”the forged iron, men, the â¬œ ğŸ‹â€™sâ€”no, no, no,â€”blistered fool! thisâœ‹ did dart it!â€”â€™tis in the ğŸŸ!â€”Aloft there! Keep him nailedâ€”Quick!â€”allâœ‹s to the rigging of the â›µsâ€”collect the oarsâ€”harpooneers! the irons, the irons!â€”hoist the royals higherâ€”a pull on all the sheets!â€”helm there! steady, steady for your life! Iâ€™ll ten times girdle the unmeasured ğŸŒ; yea and dive straight through it, but Iâ€™ll slay him yet!â€

â€œGreat God! but for one single instant show thyself,â€ cried â­ğŸ’²; â€œnever, never wilt thou capture him, old manâ€”In Jesusâ€™ name no more of this, thatâ€™s worse than ğŸ‘¿â€™s madness. Two days chased; twice stove to splinters; thy veryğŸ¦µ once more snatched from under thee; thy evil shadow goneâ€”all good angels mobbing thee with warnings:â€”what more wouldst thou have?â€”Shall we keep chasing this murderous ğŸŸ till he swamps the last man? Shall we be dragged by him to the bottom of the sea? Shall we be towed by him to the infernal world? Oh, oh,â€”Impiety and blasphemy to hunt him more!â€

â€œâ­ğŸ’², of late Iâ€™ve felt strangely moved to thee; ever since that hour we both sawâ€”thou knowâ€™st what, in one anotherâ€™s ğŸ‘€. But in this matter of the ğŸ‹, be the front of thy face to me as the palm of thisâœ‹â€”a lipless, unfeatured blank. Ahab is for ever Ahab, man. This whole actâ€™s immutably decreed. â€™Twas rehearsed by thee and me a billion years before this ocean rolled. Fool! I am the Fatesâ€™ lieutenant; I act under orders. Look thou, underling! that thou obğŸ‘€t mine.â€”Stand round me, men. Ye see an old man cut down to the stump; leaning on a shivered lance; propped up on a lonely foot. â€™Tis Ahabâ€”his bodyâ€™s part; but Ahabâ€™s soulâ€™s a centipede, that moves upon a hundredğŸ¦µs. I feel strained, half stranded, as ropes that tow dismasted frigates in a gale; and I may look so. But ere I break, yeâ€™ll hear me crack; and till ye hear that, know that Ahabâ€™s hawser tows his purpose yet. Believe ye, men, in the things called omens? Then laugh aloud, and cry encore! For ere they drown, drowning things will twice rise to the surface; then rise again, to sink for evermore. So with ğŸ³â€”two days heâ€™s floatedâ€”tomorrow will be the third. Aye, men, heâ€™ll rise once more,â€”but only to spout his last! Dâ€™ye feel brave men, brave?â€

â€œAs fearless ğŸ”¥,â€ cried Stubb.

â€œAnd as mechanical,â€ muttered Ahab. Then as the men went forward, he muttered on: â€œThe things called omens! And yesterday I talked the same to â­ğŸ’² there, concerning my broken â›µ. Oh! how valiantly I seek to drive out of othersâ€™ â¤ï¸ s whatâ€™s clinched so fast in mine!â€”The Parseeâ€”the Parsee!â€”gone, gone? and he was to go before:â€”but still was to be seen again ere I could perishâ€”Howâ€™s that?â€”Thereâ€™s a riddle now might baffle all the lawyers backed by the ghosts of the whole line of judges:â€”like a hawkâ€™s beak it pecks my brain. Iâ€™ll, Iâ€™ll solve it, though!â€

When dusk descended, the ğŸ‹ was still in sight to leeward.

So once more the sail was shortened, and everything passed nearly as on the previous night; only, the sound of hammers, and the hum of the grindstone was heard till nearly daylight, as the men toiled by lanterns in the complete and careful rigging of the spare â›µs and sharpening their fresh weapons for the morrow. Meantime, of the broken keel of Ahabâ€™s wrecked craft the carpenter made him anotherğŸ¦µ; while still as on the night before, slouched Ahab stood fixed within his scuttle; his hid, heliotrope glance anticipatingly gone backward on its dial; sat due eastward for the earliest sun.





CHAPTER 135. The Chase.â€”Third Day.

The morning of the third day dawned fair and fresh, and once more the solitary night-man at the fore-mast-head was relieved by crowds of the daylight look-outs, who dotted every mast and almost every spar.

â€œDâ€™ye see him?â€ cried Ahab; but the ğŸ‹ was not yet in sight.

â€œIn his infallible wake, though; but follow that wake, thatâ€™s all. Helm there; steady, as thou goest, and hast been going. What a lovely day again! were it a new-made world, and made for a summer-ğŸ  to the angels, and this morning the first of its throwing open to them, a fairer day could not dawn upon that world. Hereâ€™s food for thought, had Ahab time to think; but Ahab never thinks; he only feels, feels, feels; thatâ€™s tingling enough for mortal man! to thinkâ€™s audacity. God only has that right and privilege. Thinking is, or ought to be, a coolness and a calmness; and our poor â¤ï¸ s throb, and our poor brains beat too much for that. And yet, Iâ€™ve sometimes thought my brain was very calmâ€”frozen calm, this old ğŸ’€ cracks so, like a glass in which the contents turned to ice, and shiver it. And still this hair is growing now; this moment growing, and heat must breed it; but no, itâ€™s like that sort of common grass that will grow anywhere, between the earthy clefts of Greenland ice or in Vesuvius lava. How the wild winds blow it; they whip it about me as the torn shreds of split sails lash the tossedğŸš¢ they cling to. A vile wind that has no doubt blown ere this through prison corridors and cells, and wards of hospitals, and ventilated them, and now comes blowing hither as innocent as fleeces. Out upon it!â€”itâ€™s tainted. Were I the wind, Iâ€™d blow no more on such a wicked, miserable world. Iâ€™d crawl somewhere to a cave, and slink there. And yet, â€™tis a noble and heroic thing, the wind! who ever conquered it? In every fight it has the last and bitterest blow. Run tilting at it, and you but run through it. Ha! a coward wind that strikes stark naked men, but will not stand to receive a single blow. Even Ahab is a braver thingâ€”a nobler thing than that. Would now the wind but had a body; but all the things that most exasperate and outrage mortal man, all these things are bodiless, but only bodiless as objects, not as agents. Thereâ€™s a most special, a most cunning, oh, a most malicious difference! And yet, I say again, and swear it now, that thereâ€™s something all glorious and gracious in the wind. These warm Trade Winds, at least, that in the clear heavens blow straight on, in strong and steadfast, vigorous mildness; and veer not from their mark, however the baser currents of the sea may turn and tack, and mightiest Mississippies of the land swift and swerve about, uncertain where to go at last. And by the eternal Poles! these same Trades that so directly blow my goodğŸš¢ on; these Trades, or something like themâ€”something so unchangeable, and full as strong, blow my keeled soul along! To it! Aloft there! What dâ€™ye see?â€

â€œNothing, sir.â€

â€œNothing! and noon atâœ‹! The doubloon goes a-begging! See the sun! Aye, aye, it must be so. Iâ€™ve oversailed him. How, got the start? Aye, heâ€™s chasing me now; not I, himâ€”thatâ€™s bad; I might have known it, too. Fool! the linesâ€”the harpoons heâ€™s towing. Aye, aye, I have run him by last night. About! about! Come down, all of ye, but the regular look outs! Man the braces!â€

Steering as she had done, the wind had been somewhat on the Pequodâ€™s quarter, so that now being pointed in the reverse direction, the bracedğŸš¢ sailed hard upon the breeze as she rechurned the cream in her own â¬œ wake.

â€œAgainst the wind he now steers for the open jaw,â€ murmured â­ğŸ’² to himself, as he coiled the new-hauled main-brace upon the rail. â€œGod keep us, but already my bones feel damp within me, and from the inside wet my flesh. I misdoubt me that I disobey my God in obeying him!â€

â€œStand by to sway me up!â€ cried Ahab, advancing to the hempen basket. â€œWe should meet him soon.â€

â€œAye, aye, sir,â€ and straightway â­ğŸ’² did Ahabâ€™s bidding, and once more Ahab swung on high.

A whole hour now passed; gold-beaten out to ages. Time itself now held long breaths with keen suspense. But at last, some three points off the weather bow, Ahab descried the spout again, and instantly from the three mast-heads three shrieks went up as if the tongues of ğŸ”¥ had voiced it.

â€œForehead to forehead I meet thee, this third time, ğŸ³! On deck there!â€”brace sharper up; crowd her into the windâ€™s eye. Heâ€™s too far off to lower yet, Mr. â­ğŸ’². The sails shake! Stand over that helmsman with a top-maul! So, so; he travels fast, and I must down. But let me have one more good round look aloft here at the sea; thereâ€™s time for that. An old, old sight, and yet somehow so young; aye, and not changed a wink since I first saw it, a boy, from the sand-hills of Nantucket! The same!â€”the same!â€”the same to Noah as to me. Thereâ€™s a soft shower to leeward. Such lovely leewardings! They must lead somewhereâ€”to something else than common land, more palmy than the palms. Leeward! the â¬œ ğŸ‹ goes that way; look to windward, then; the better if the bitterer quarter. But good bye, good bye, old mast-head! Whatâ€™s this?â€”green? aye, tiny mosses in these warped cracks. No such green weather stains on Ahabâ€™s head! Thereâ€™s the difference now between manâ€™s old age and matterâ€™s. But aye, old mast, we both grow old together; sound in our hulls, though, are we not, myğŸš¢? Aye, minus ağŸ¦µ, thatâ€™s all. By heaven this dead wood has the better of my live flesh every way. I canâ€™t compare with it; and Iâ€™ve known someğŸš¢s made of dead trees outlast the lives of men made of the most vital stuff of vital fathers. Whatâ€™s that he said? he should still go before me, my pilot; and yet to be seen again? But where? Will I have ğŸ‘€ at the bottom of the sea, supposing I descend those endless stairs? and all night Iâ€™ve been sailing from him, wherever he did sink to. Aye, aye, like many more thou toldâ€™st direful truth as touching thyself, O Parsee; but, Ahab, there thy shot fell short. Good-bye, mast-headâ€”keep a good eye upon the ğŸ‹, the while Iâ€™m gone. Weâ€™ll talk to-morrow, nay, to-night, when the â¬œ ğŸ‹ lies down there, tied by head and tail.â€

He gave the word; and still gazing round him, was steadily lowered through the cloven blue air to the deck.

In due time the â›µs were lowered; but as standing in his shallopâ€™s stern, Ahab just hovered upon the point of the descent, he ğŸŒŠd to the mate,â€”who held one of the tackle-ropes on deckâ€”and bade him pause.

â€œâ­ğŸ’²!â€

â€œSir?â€

â€œFor the third time my soulâ€™sğŸš¢ starts upon this voyage, â­ğŸ’².â€

â€œAye, sir, thou wilt have it so.â€

â€œSomeğŸš¢s sail from their ports, and ever afterwards are missing, â­ğŸ’²!â€

â€œTruth, sir: saddest truth.â€

â€œSome men die at ebb tide; some at low water; some at the full of the flood;â€”and I feel now like a billow thatâ€™s all one crested comb, â­ğŸ’². I am old;â€”shakeâœ‹s with me, man.â€

Theirâœ‹s met; their ğŸ‘€ fastened; â­ğŸ’²â€™s tears the glue.

â€œOh, my captain, my captain!â€”noble â¤ï¸ â€”go notâ€”go not!â€”see, itâ€™s a brave man that weeps; how great the agony of the persuasion then!â€

â€œLower away!â€â€”cried Ahab, tossing the mateâ€™sğŸ’ª from him. â€œStand by the crew!â€

In an instant the â›µ was pulling round close under the stern.

â€œThe ğŸ¦ˆs! the ğŸ¦ˆs!â€ cried a voice from the low cabin-window there; â€œO master, my master, come back!â€

But Ahab heard nothing; for his own voice was high-lifted then; and the â›µ leaped on.

Yet the voice spake true; for scarce had he pushed from theğŸš¢, when numbers of ğŸ¦ˆs, seemingly rising from out the dark waters beneath the hull, maliciously snapped at the blades of the oars, every time they dipped in the water; and in this way accompanied the â›µ with their bites. It is a thing not uncommonly happening to the ğŸ‹-â›µs in those swarming seas; the ğŸ¦ˆs at times apparently following them in the same prescient way that vultures hover over the banners of marching regiments in the east. But these were the first ğŸ¦ˆs that had been observed by the Pequod since the â¬œ ğŸ‹ had been first descried; and whether it was that Ahabâ€™s crew were all such tiger-yellow barbarians, and therefore their flesh more musky to the senses of the ğŸ¦ˆsâ€”a matter sometimes well known to affect them,â€”however it was, they seemed to follow that one â›µ without molesting the others.

â€œHeart of wrought steel!â€ murmured â­ğŸ’² gazing over the side, and following with his ğŸ‘€ the receding â›µâ€”â€œcanst thou yet ring boldly to that sight?â€”lowering thy keel among ravening ğŸ¦ˆs, and followed by them, open-mouthed to the chase; and this the critical third day?â€”For when three days flow together in one continuous intense pursuit; be sure the first is the morning, the second the noon, and the third the evening and the end of that thingâ€”be that end what it may. Oh! my God! what is this that shoots through me, and leaves me so deadly calm, yet expectant,â€”fixed at the top of a shudder! Future things swim before me, as in empty outlines and skeletons; all the past is somehow grown dim. Mary, girl! thou fadest in pale glories behind me; boy! I seem to see but thy ğŸ‘€ grown wondrous blue. Strangest problems of life seem clearing; but clouds sweep betweenâ€”Is my journeyâ€™s end coming? MyğŸ¦µs feel faint; like his who has footed it all day. Feel thy â¤ï¸ ,â€”beats it yet? Stir thyself, â­ğŸ’²!â€”stave it offâ€”move, move! speak aloud!â€”Mast-head there! See ye my boyâ€™sâœ‹ on the hill?â€”Crazed;â€”aloft there!â€”keep thy keenest eye upon the â›µs:â€”mark well the ğŸ‹!â€”Ho! again!â€”drive off that hawk! see! he pecksâ€”he tears the vaneâ€â€”pointing to the red flag flying at the main-truckâ€”â€œHa! he soars away with it!â€”Whereâ€™s the old man now? seeâ€™st thou that sight, oh Ahab!â€”shudder, shudder!â€

The â›µs had not gone very far, when by a signal from the mast-headsâ€”a downward pointedğŸ’ª, Ahab knew that the ğŸ‹ had sounded; but intending to be near him at the next rising, he held on his way a little sideways from the vessel; the becharmed crew maintaining the profoundest silence, as the head-beat ğŸŒŠ hammered and hammered against the opposing bow.

â€œDrive, drive in your nails, oh ye ğŸŒŠ! to their uttermost heads drive them in! ye but strike a thing without a lid; and no âš°ï¸ and no hearse can be mine:â€”and hemp only can kill me! Ha! ha!â€

Suddenly the waters around them slowly swelled in broad circles; then quickly upheaved, as if sideways sliding from a submerged berg of ice, swiftly rising to the surface. A low rumbling sound was heard; a subterraneous hum; and then all held their breaths; as ğŸ›ï¸raggled with trailing ropes, and harpoons, and lances, a vast form shot lengthwise, but obliquely from the sea. Shrouded in a thin drooping veil of mist, it hovered for a moment in the rainbowed air; and then fell swamping back into the deep. Crushed thirty feet upwards, the waters flashed for an instant like heaps of fountains, then brokenly sank in a shower of flakes, leaving the circling surface creamed like new milk round the marble trunk of the ğŸ‹.

â€œGive way!â€ cried Ahab to the oarsmen, and the â›µs darted forward to the attack; but maddened by yesterdayâ€™s fresh irons that corroded in him, ğŸ³ seemed combinedly possessed by all the angels that fell from heaven. The wide tiers of welded tendons overspreading his broad â¬œ forehead, beneath the transparent skin, looked knitted together; as head on, he came churning his tail among the â›µs; and once more flailed them apart; spilling out the irons and lances from the two matesâ€™ â›µs, and dashing in one side of the upper part of their bows, but leaving Ahabâ€™s almost without a scar.

While Daggoo and Queequeg were stopping the strained planks; and as the ğŸ‹ swimming out from them, turned, and showed one entire flank as he shot by them again; at that moment a quick cry went up. Lashed round and round to the ğŸŸâ€™s back; pinioned in the turns upon turns in which, during the past night, the ğŸ‹ had reeled the involutions of the lines around him, the half torn body of the Parsee was seen; his sable raiment frayed to shreds; his distended ğŸ‘€ turned full upon old Ahab.

The harpoon dropped from hisâœ‹.

â€œBefooled, befooled!â€â€”drawing in a long lean breathâ€”â€œAye, Parsee! I see thee again.â€”Aye, and thou goest before; and this, this then is the hearse that thou didst promise. But I hold thee to the last letter of thy word. Where is the second hearse? Away, mates, to theğŸš¢! those â›µs are useless now; repair them if ye can in time, and return to me; if not, Ahab is enough to dieâ€”Down, men! the first thing that but offers to jump from this â›µ I stand in, that thing I harpoon. Ye are not other men, but myğŸ’ªs and myğŸ¦µs; and so obey me.â€”Whereâ€™s the ğŸ‹? gone down again?â€

But he looked too nigh the â›µ; for as if bent upon escaping with the corpse he bore, and as if the particular place of the last encounter had been but a stage in his leeward voyage, ğŸ³ was now again steadily swimming forward; and had almost passed theğŸš¢,â€”which thus far had been sailing in the contrary direction to him, though for the present her headway had been stopped. He seemed swimming with his utmost velocity, and now only intent upon pursuing his own straight path in the sea.

â€œOh! Ahab,â€ cried â­ğŸ’², â€œnot too late is it, even now, the third day, to desist. See! ğŸ³ seeks thee not. It is thou, thou, that madly seekest him!â€

Setting sail to the rising wind, the lonely â›µ was swiftly impelled to leeward, by both oars and canvas. And at last when Ahab was sliding by the vessel, so near as plainly to distinguish â­ğŸ’²â€™s face as he leaned over the rail, he hailed him to turn the vessel about, and follow him, not too swiftly, at a judicious interval. Glancing upwards, he saw Tashtego, Queequeg, and Daggoo, eagerly mounting to the three mast-heads; while the oarsmen were rocking in the two staved â›µs which had but just been hoisted to the side, and were busily at work in repairing them. One after the other, through the port-holes, as he sped, he also caught flying glimpses of Stubb and Flask, busying themselves on deck among bundles of new irons and lances. As he saw all this; as he heard the hammers in the broken â›µs; far other hammers seemed driving a nail into his â¤ï¸ . But he rallied. And now marking that the vane or flag was gone from the main-mast-head, he shouted to Tashtego, who had just gained that perch, to descend again for another flag, and a hammer and nails, and so nail it to the mast.

Whether fagged by the three daysâ€™ running chase, and the resistance to his swimming in the knotted hamper he bore; or whether it was some latent deceitfulness and malice in him: whichever was true, the â¬œ ğŸ‹â€™s way now began to abate, as it seemed, from the â›µ so rapidly nearing him once more; though indeed the ğŸ‹â€™s last start had not been so long a one as before. And still as Ahab glided over the ğŸŒŠ the unpitying ğŸ¦ˆs accompanied him; and so pertinaciously stuck to the â›µ; and so continually bit at the plying oars, that the blades became jagged and crunched, and left small splinters in the sea, at almost every dip.

â€œHeed them not! those teeth but give new rowlocks to your oars. Pull on! â€™tis the better rest, the ğŸ¦ˆâ€™s jaw than the yielding water.â€

â€œBut at every bite, sir, the thin blades grow smaller and smaller!â€

â€œThey will last long enough! pull on!â€”But who can tellâ€â€”he mutteredâ€”â€œwhether these ğŸ¦ˆs swim to feast on the ğŸ‹ or on Ahab?â€”But pull on! Aye, all alive, nowâ€”we near him. The helm! take the helm! let me pass,â€â€”and so saying two of the oarsmen helped him forward to the bows of the still flying â›µ.

At length as the craft was cast to one side, and ran ranging along with the â¬œ ğŸ‹â€™s flank, he seemed strangely oblivious of its advanceâ€”as the ğŸ‹ sometimes willâ€”and Ahab was fairly within the smoky mountain mist, which, thrown off from the ğŸ‹â€™s spout, curled round his great, Monadnock hump; he was even thus close to him; when, with body arched back, and bothğŸ’ªs lengthwise high-lifted to the poise, he darted his fierce iron, and his far fiercer curse into the hated ğŸ‹. As both steel and curse sank to the socket, as if sucked into a morass, ğŸ³ sideways writhed; spasmodically rolled his nigh flank against the bow, and, without staving a hole in it, so suddenly canted the â›µ over, that had it not been for the elevated part of the gunwale to which he then clung, Ahab would once more have been tossed into the sea. As it was, three of the oarsmenâ€”who foreknew not the precise instant of the dart, and were therefore unprepared for its effectsâ€”these were flung out; but so fell, that, in an instant two of them clutched the gunwale again, and rising to its level on a combing ğŸŒŠ, hurled themselves bodily inboard again; the third man helplessly dropping astern, but still afloat and swimming.

Almost simultaneously, with a mighty volition of ungraduated, instantaneous swiftness, the â¬œ ğŸ‹ darted through the weltering sea. But when Ahab cried out to the steersman to take new turns with the line, and hold it so; and commanded the crew to turn round on their seats, and tow the â›µ up to the mark; the moment the treacherous line felt that double strain and tug, it snapped in the empty air!

â€œWhat breaks in me? Some sinew cracks!â€”â€™tis whole again; oars! oars! Burst in upon him!â€

Hearing the tremendous rush of the sea-crashing â›µ, the ğŸ‹ wheeled round to present his blank forehead at bay; but in that evolution, catching sight of the nearing black hull of theğŸš¢; seemingly seeing in it the source of all his persecutions; bethinking itâ€”it may beâ€”a larger and nobler foe; of a sudden, he bore down upon its advancing prow, smiting his jaws amid fiery showers of foam.

Ahab staggered; hisâœ‹ smote his forehead. â€œI grow blind;âœ‹s! stretch out before me that I may yet grope my way. Isâ€™t night?â€

â€œThe ğŸ‹! TheğŸš¢!â€ cried the cringing oarsmen.

â€œOars! oars! Slope downwards to thy depths, O sea, that ere it be for ever too late, Ahab may slide this last, last time upon his mark! I see: theğŸš¢! theğŸš¢! Dash on, my men! Will ye not save myğŸš¢?â€

But as the oarsmen violently forced their â›µ through the sledge-hammering seas, the before ğŸ‹-smitten bow-ends of two planks burst through, and in an instant almost, the temporarily disabled â›µ lay nearly level with the ğŸŒŠ; its half-wading, splashing crew, trying hard to stop the gap and bale out the pouring water.

Meantime, for that one beholding instant, Tashtegoâ€™s mast-head hammer remained suspended in hisâœ‹; and the red flag, half-wrapping him as with a plaid, then streamed itself straight out from him, as his own forward-flowing â¤ï¸ ; while â­ğŸ’² and Stubb, standing upon the bowsprit beneath, caught sight of the down-coming monster just as soon as he.

â€œThe ğŸ‹, the ğŸ‹! Up helm, up helm! Oh, all ye sweet powers of air, now hug me close! Let not â­ğŸ’² die, if die he must, in a womanâ€™s fainting fit. Up helm, I sayâ€”ye fools, the jaw! the jaw! Is this the end of all my bursting prayers? all my life-long fidelities? Oh, Ahab, Ahab, lo, thy work. Steady! helmsman, steady. Nay, nay! Up helm again! He turns to meet us! Oh, his unappeasable brow drives on towards one, whose duty tells him he cannot depart. My God, stand by me now!â€
